question: Good morning.
answer: Listen to this -- the entire work force of the state of Virginia had to have solitaire removed from their computers -- -- because they hadn't done any work in six weeks.

question: Aren't you late?
answer: You know what this is, you know what we're seeing here? We're seeing the end of Western civilization as we know it.

question: This is so sad.
answer: You think that machine is your friend, but it's not. I'm late.

question: I'll see you tonight.
answer: Sushi.

question: -- although he likes to eat bits of pizza and bagel off the sidewalk, and I prefer to buy them. Brinkley is a great catcher and was offered a tryout on the Mets farm team -- Mmmmmhmmm --
answer: I'm late. Random House fired Dick Atkins. Good riddance. Murray Chilton died. Which makes one less person I'm not speaking to -- Vince got a great review. He'll be insufferable. Tonight, PEN dinner --

question: Am I going?
answer: You promised.

question: Can't I just give them money? That's the cause? Free Albanian writers? I'm for that. All right, I'll go. You're late.
answer: I know I know I know.

question: I like to start my notes to you as if we're already in the middle of a conversation. I pretend that we're the oldest and dearest friends -- as opposed to what we actually are, people who don't know each other's names and met in a Chat Room where we both claimed we'd never been before. Hello, Christina. It's a beautiful day. Isn't it the most beautiful day?
answer: I guess. Yeah, sure.

question: Don't you love New York in the fall?
answer: What's going on with you?

question: Nothing.
answer: You're in love.

question: In love? No. Yes. Of course I am. I'm in love with Frank. I'm practically living with Frank. Do you think you could get our Christmas mailers out this week?
answer: By Monday I promise. I have a paper due Friday. Now what's going on? I'm just going to stand here till you tell me.

question: Is it infidelity if you're involved with someone on E-mail?
answer: Have you had sex?

question: Of course not. I don't even know him.
answer: I mean cybersex.

question: No!
answer: Well, don't do it. The minute you do, they lose all respect for you.

question: It's not like that. We just E-mail. It's really nothing, on top of which I'm definitely thinking of stopping because it's getting --
answer: Out of hand?

question: Confusing. But not really. Because it's nothing.
answer: Where did you meet him?

question: I can't even remember. The day I turned thirty I wandered into the Over Thirty Room for a joke, sort of and he was there, and we started chatting.
answer: About what?

question: Books. Music. How much we both love New York. Harmless. Harmless. Meaningless. Bouquets of sharpened pencils.
answer: Excuse me?

question: Forget it. We don't talk about anything personal. We made a rule about that. I don't know his name, what he does or exactly where he lives, so it will be really easy to stop seeing him, because I'm not.
answer: God, he could be the next person to talk into the store. He could be... George.

question: The electrical contractor called. His truck hit a deer last night, he won't be in 'til tomorrow. The shelves are late because the shipment of pine had beetles. And there's some question about whether we're installing the stairs in the right spot --
answer: That sounds great.

question: Testing one two three four.
answer: Is the electrician here?

question: I just told you -- he hit a deer.
answer: I hear nothing. Not a sound on the city streets, just the beat of my own heart. I think that's the way it goes. Something like that.

question: Did you and Patricia get engaged?
answer: Engaged? Are you crazy?

question: I thought you liked Patricia --
answer: I love Patricia. Patricia's amazing. Patricia makes coffee nervous. Are we still on schedule?

question: We open two weeks before Thanksgiving.
answer: I guess we should announce ourselves soon. Tell people we're coming.

question: This is the Upper West Side of Manhattan. The minute they hear they'll be lining up
answer: -- to picket --

question: -- the big bad --
answer: --chain store --

question: -- that destroys --
answer: -- everything we hold dear. But we'll seduce them with our square footage and our deep armchairs and our amazingly swift checkout lines and our discounts and our... They hate us in the beginning, but we get them in the end. Meanwhile we should just put up a sign -- Coming soon, a Foxbooks Superstore and The End of Western Civilization As We Know It. Kevin and I are both a little concerned about the neighborhood response -- What is this fabric? Does it have a name?

question: What's the competition?
answer: One mystery store. Sleuth, on 86th and Amsterdam. And a children's bookstore. The Shop Around the Corner. Been there forever.

question: Cecilia's store.
answer: Who's that?

question: Cecilia Kelly, lovely woman. I think we might have had a date once. Or maybe we just exchange letters.
answer: You wrote her letters?

question: My father is getting married again. For five years he's been living with a woman who studied decorating at Caesar's Palace.
answer: Once I read a story about a butterfly in the subway, and today I saw one. I couldn't believe it. It got on at 42nd -- and got off at 59th, where I assume it was going to Bloomindale's to buy a hat that will turn out to be a mistake. As almost all hats are.

question: Did you know that every night a truck pulls up to H&H Bagels and pumps about a ton of flour into the ground? The air is absolutely amazing.
answer: I guess I've read Pride & Prejudice about 100 times -- -- and every time I read it I worry that Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy are not going to get together -- but the truth is whenever I think about my favorite book I always think about the books I read as a child --

question: Did you ever read Homer Price? My all- time favorite children's book.
answer: Have you been to Krispy Kreme?

question: Yes! Who was she?
answer: I don't know. She was standing outside my building with the police and the reporters.

question: What police and reporters?
answer: Someone died.

question: Who?
answer: I have no idea about that either. They found her on the roof.

question: A dead body. That's so sad. But you fell in love. That's so great.
answer: Oh. One other thing.

question: When you are finished with Foxbooks, the Shop Around the Corner is going to be responsible for reversing the entire course of the Industrial Revolution.
answer: That is so sweet, Frank. Thank you. That is so sweet.

question: Hey --
answer: Although...

question: What?
answer: What is that doing there?

question: Listen to it. Just listen-- The Olympia Report deluxe Electric Report. As in gunshot.
answer: That sound is familiar.

question: Now listen to this.
answer: That whirring?

question: The gentle and soothing lullaby of a piece of machinery so perfect --
answer: I know where I've heard it before. I know.

question: I needed a backup.
answer: Don't you have another one at your apartment?

question: I might, I might. So what?
answer: You're turning my apartment into a typewriter museum.

question: I'll stop. I'll try. I probably can't. I see one and my knees go weak. Anyway, what were you starting to say?
answer: When?

question: Before.
answer: Nothing.

question: Come on.
answer: I don't know. I was just wondering about my work and all. I mean, what is it I do exactly? All I really do is run a bookstore --

question: All you really do is this incredibly noble thing --
answer: But I don't know if I --

question: Kathleen --
answer: But I just --

question: You are a lone reed. You are a lone reed waving in the breeze standing strong and tall in the corrupt sands of commerce.
answer: I am a lone reed. I am a lone reed. Sometimes I wonder about my life. I lead a small life. Well, not small, but circumscribed. And sometimes I wonder, do I do it because I like it, or because I haven't been brave? So much of what I see reminds me of something I read in a book, when shouldn't it be the other way around?

question: I am a lone reed. I am a lone reed. Sometimes I wonder about my life. I lead a small life. Well, not small, but circumscribed. And sometimes I wonder, do I do it because I like it, or because I haven't been brave? So much of what I see reminds me of something I read in a book, when shouldn't it be the other way around?
answer: I went to the Foxbooks Website and you can buy anything. They ship it to you in a day. Maybe we should get a website.

question: My mother would never have wanted us to have a website. "Every book you sell is a gift from your heart." She always said that.
answer: What if they put us out of business?

question: It's out of the question. We're a fixture in the neighborhood. We're practically a landmark. Men For Women, Women for Men, Women for Women -- what is this?
answer: You fill out one of these forms and they file it in the book and if someone wants to meet you, they arrange it.

question: What a stupid way to meet someone.
answer: Compared to the Internet?

question: My little thing on the Internet is just a lark.
answer: So it's still going on?

question: And I do not plan to meet him. Why do I get the feeling that you are in here somewhere?
answer: I came in here one night and drank too much coffee and filled one out. Well how am I supposed to meet someone?

question: You are a runner. Some day you will make eye contact with another runner and --
answer: No one ever even looks at me. They don't. On top of which, who are they? They could like the symphony. I could never fall in love with someone who likes to go to the symphony --

question: I know. What are you supposed to do there?
answer: I don't know.

question: Sit. You're supposed to sit.
answer: I could never fall in love with anyone who smokes cigars either.

question: I'll tell you what I hate. Big fat legs like stumps.
answer: Yeah. I hate that too.

question: The worst, the worst -- I could never, under any circumstances, love anybody who had a sailboat.
answer: Neither could I.

question: If I had to get up on Saturday morning knowing that I was about to go down to the pier and unravel all those ropes and put on all that sunblock --
answer: All that talk about the wind.

question: And then you have to go out on the boat, and you sail and sail and sail until you are bored witless, and then, only then, do they say, let's turn around and you realize the trip is only half over, only it's not, because the wind has changed --
answer: It hasn't changed. It's died.

question: So then there's more talk about the wind. While you just float up and down trying not to get nauseous. And when you finally get back, you have to clean up the boat.
answer: Why don't people have boat maids?

question: Joe --
answer: Hello. Annabel, how are you today?

question: Great.
answer: Hey, big guy -- Hello, Gillian. Who is this?

question: Maureen's getting a divorce.
answer: I'm sorry to hear that. That is so wise. Remember that, Annabel.

question: I want all of them.
answer: That might be an awful lot for your dad to buy at one time.

question: My dad gets me all the books I want.
answer: Well, that's very nice of him.

question: That's not my dad. That's my nephew --
answer: Oh, I don't really think that's your nephew --

question: You know what else children don't know? They don't know what a telephone booth is?
answer: Who are you?

question: Kathleen Kelly. I own this store. Are you are?
answer: Joe. Just call me Joe. We'll take these books.

question: -- likes to buy at discount. Don't tell anyone that, Annabel, it's nothing to be proud of --
answer: That's amazing. You can spell fox. Can you spell dog?

question: Matt, look at this dinosaur book. Wouldn't you like a dinosaur book? Annabel, maybe you could read this to Matt while I wrap things up here. Sit down, read, and don't listen to anything I say. And the dinosaur book too.
answer: The world is not driven by discounts, believe me. I've been in business forever. I started helping my mother here after school when I was six years old. I used to watch her, and it wasn't that she was selling books, it was that she was helping people become whoever they were going to turn out to be. When you read a book as a child it becomes part of your identity in a way that no other reading in your life does. I guess I've gotten carried away.

question: You have, and you've made me feel...
answer: She was. How did you know that?

question: Lucky guess.
answer: Anyway. She left the store to me, and I'm going to leave it to my daughter.

question: How old is your daughter now?
answer: Oh, I'm not married. But eventually. So Foxbooks can... Here you go.

question: What's my car number? Are you an idiot? Of course I need a car. God! Taxi! Taxi! Taxi! Excuse me -- what are you doing? This is my taxicab. Don't take him. I am telling you right now, and I am memorizing your number, don't take him. Who the fuck do you think you are?
answer: Are you going uptown?

question: Yes.
answer: Get in. I'll drop you.

question: Veronica, it's Patricia, you should have been there, it was unbelievable, we're going to sell truckloads of your book. Call me.
answer: Are you an editor?

question: Yes.
answer: I am a rabbi.

question: Oh, my God, I said fuck to a rabbi. I'm sorry.
answer: I hope you don't mind my asking, but are you Jewish?

question: Yes.
answer: You should come to our temple.

question: I'm not really religious.
answer: Oh, I am surprised, you seem like a very religious person.

question: You're kidding, right?
answer: We are at West End Avenue and 83rd Street. Every Friday night, we have a joyous time, everyone dancing, everyone singing. Also some wisdom. Perhaps you have heard of us, we are known as The Singles Temple. It's a very good place to calm down. Oh, look, I am already here. Very nice to meet you. Take this woman to her destination.

question: I saw him. I actually saw him.
answer: Who?

question: I can't believe it. I saw William Spungeon.
answer: I thought he was in Mexico.

question: Maybe he's in Mexico, but today he was in New York. The most brilliant and reclusive novelist in the history of the world is here, in this neighborhood. He may be living on this very block.
answer: Where did you see him?

question: I was on the subway -- -- and this musician got onto the train -- -- and I suddenly saw him, sitting directly across from me doing the crossword puzzle.
answer: How'd you know it was him?

question: He looked exactly the same as his high school yearbook picture, which happens to be the last photograph ever taken of him. So I followed him. He went into H&H and bought a bagel with everything. He dropped his crossword into the garbage and I rescued it. Then he went into a sporting good store and bought tube socks, 6 pair for $7.99.
answer: William Spungeon and tube socks.

question: I know. I don't want to dwell on it. And then I lost him. Do you know what this is worth? What I was thinking as I was trailing him was that eventually I would have the courage to say hello to him, you know, not in a horrible, intrusive or slavering fan-slash-acolyte kind of way, but more like, "Hi." "How ya doing?" "Have you ever thought about trading up in the sock area?" "Who knows, maybe he's read my work -- and then we'd become friends, and eventually I'd introduce him to you -- you know how much he loves children's books, there's a whole long section in Relativity's Smile about The Wizard of Oz -- and then maybe he'd come out of hiding so he could help save the store.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: From Foxbooks. I mean, if things got tough, he could help rally support --
answer: It's never going to get to that. The store is fine.

question: I don't even know why you would say that?
answer: Neither do I. It just flew out of my mouth.

question: There's enough business for us all.
answer: I mean, we're fine.

question: You're more than fine, you're absolutely fine.
answer: We're fine.

question: Absolut on the rocks.
answer: A white wine, please. Oh, hello.

question: Hi.
answer: Remember me, from the bookstore?

question: Of course I remember you.
answer: How's your aunt?

question: Good. She's good. I have to deliver this. I have a very thirsty date. She's part camel.
answer: Joe. It's Joe, isn't it?

question: And you're Kathleen.
answer: Joe Fox? As in -- Fox? Your last name is Fox? God, I didn't realize. I didn't know who you --

question: -- were with. "I didn't know who you were with."
answer: Excuse me?

question: It's from the Godfather. When the movie producer realizes that Tom Hagen is the emissary of Vito Corleone --
answer: You were spying on me, weren't you? You probably rented those children.

question: Why would I spy on you?
answer: I am your competition. Which you know perfectly well or you would not have put up that sign saying "Just around the Corner."

question: The entrance to our store is around the corner. There is no other way to say it. It's not the name of our store, it's where it is. You don't own "around the corner."
answer: Next thing you'll be using twinkle lights.

question: Twinkle lights?
answer: Little white Christmas lights that twinkle. I use them in my window and on all my displays, as if you didn't notice.

question: Look, the reason I came into your store is that I was spending the day with Annabel and Matt. I like to buy them a present when I see them because I'm one of those guys who likes to buy his way into the hearts of children who are his relatives. There was only one place to buy children's books in the neighborhood -- although that will not always be the case, and it was yours, and it is a charming little bookstore. You probably sell $250,000 worth of book a year --
answer: How do you know that?

question: I'm in the book business.
answer: I'm in the book business --

question: I don't think it's a good idea for us to meet...
answer: About $1200 less than the same week last year.

question: That could be a fluke, right?
answer: Or not.

question: Their store is new. It's a novelty. But it will all shake out. Do you think I should put up more twinkle lights?
answer: That's a lovely idea.

question: Mr. Pappas, I'm investigating the murder of the woman found on the roof of your building. Do you live alone there?
answer: Do I live alone? Yes I do. Do you live alone?

question: Yes. What are you doing?
answer: I don't know. I have no idea.

question: You have to stop.
answer: I can't.

question: What? Omigod, I only have a credit card. Is that okay?
answer: Oh, hello.

question: Hello.
answer: Do you need some money?

question: No, I don't need any money. Thank you very much.
answer: Hi. Rose. Great name. Rose, this is Kathleen, I'm Joe, and this is a credit card machine. Happy Thanksgiving. Mississippi is a hard word to spell. How do you spell it? I-T. Now take this credit card and put it through the machine, zip zip. So you're fine.

question: Fine.
answer: Happy Thanksgiving.

question: I had a gut feeling you would be on line now.
answer: I don't think you can help.

question: Is it about love?
answer: My business is in trouble. My mother would have something wise to say.

question: I'm a brilliant businessman. It's what I do best. What's your business?
answer: No specifics, remember?

question: Minus specifics, it's hard to help. Except to say, go to the mattresses.
answer: What?

question: It's from The Godfather. It means you have to go to war.
answer: The Godfather? What is it with men and The Godfather?

question: The Godfather is the I Ching. The Godfather is the sum of all wisdom. The Godfather is the answer to any question. What should I pack for my summer vacation? "Leave the gun, take the cannoli." What day of the week is it? "Maunday, Tuesday, Thursday, Wednesday." And the answer to your question is "Go to the mattresses."
answer: Look what I bought. I was just passing this store on Columbus Avenue and it caught my eye.

question: What is it?
answer: A Menorah.

question: It doesn't look like a Menorah.
answer: I know. I don't know what came over me. I don't even celebrate Hanukkah.

question: Omigod.
answer: It's him.

question: Who?
answer: God. It is God.

question: She's not as nice as she seems on television.
answer: You've met her?

question: She's kind of a pill.
answer: She's probably not as attractive as she seems on television either.

question: No, she's beautiful. But a pill.
answer: So you don't feel bad about basically destroying her livelihood not to mention her legacy not to mention her raison d'etre.

question: It's not personal --
answer: It's business.

question: Right. Exactly. I sell cheap books. Sue me. I sell cheap books, and as a result -- listen to this, because it's really bad -- more people can buy books.
answer: That's what you said?

question: That's not all I said. I said -- I can't believe those bastards -- I said we were great, I said people can come and sit and read for hours and no one bothers them, I said we stock 150,000 titles, I showed them the New York City section. I said we were a goddamn piazza where people could mingle and mix and be.
answer: A piazza?

question: I was eloquent. Shit. It's just inevitable, isn't it? People are going to want to turn her into Joan of Arc --
answer: -- and you into Attila the Hun.

question: Technologically speaking, the world's out of hand. Take the VCR. The whole idea of a VCR is that it makes it possible for you to tape what's on television while you're out of the house. But the whole point of being out of the house is so you can miss what's on television. Radio. Now there's a medium I can get behind.
answer: Well, we're on television... and you're good at it.

question: Thank you.
answer: The bookstore. Tell us about it.

question: Are you planning to collect radios?
answer: Do you think I should?

question: The Shop Around the Corner is a true New York treasure.
answer: As are you. I'd love to have you back.

question: Any time. Are we done?
answer: Not at all.

question: Spare us.
answer: Don't tell me. Not the slightest difference?

question: Let's ask her. Cecilia, what should we do?
answer: Birdie?

question: Shhhh. She has no idea, but she thinks the window display is lovely. Good night dearie.
answer: Oh my goodness, hello. What are you doing here.

question: Oh my goodness, hello. What are you doing here.
answer: Loitering. Lurking. Skulking. Stalking.

question: Thank you. But I'm a wreck.
answer: An eyelash. It's gone.

question: Are you writing another book?
answer: I'm in the home stretch. I'll be done in approximately six more years.

question: Should I discount?
answer: It's about a man on a quest for knowledge who meets a woman he cannot resist.

question: If I discount I have to fire someone because I can't discount with this overhead but whom could I fire? I couldn't fire anyone.
answer: You have your mother's hair. Thick, wild, the color of Nebraska wheat.

question: What are you doing? Let me go. Stop it. Are you crazy?
answer: If you change your mind, you can E-mail me. Hermit@AOL.com.

question: I suppose she's carrying a copy of a book with a flower in it. Not really.
answer: Really.

question: Which Jane Austen is it?
answer: Pride and Prejudice.

question: She could be a real dog.
answer: I know. Look, I'll just stay ten minutes. I'll say hello. Drink a cup of coffee and split. I'm outta here. What if she has a really high, squeaky voice? I hate that. It reminds me of those mice in Cinderella.

question: What mice in Cinderella?
answer: Gus-gus and oh shit, I can't remember the other one. Why am I compelled to meet her? I'm just ruining a good thing.

question: You're taking it to the next level. I always do that. I always take a relationship to the next level, and if it works okay I take it to the next level after that, until I can finally get to the level where it becomes absolutely necessary for me to leave.
answer: I'm not going to stay long anyway. I already said that, didn't I. Christ. I'm a total wreck. Kevin, this woman is the most adorable creature I have ever come in contact with. If she turns out to be even as good-looking as a mailbox, I will be crazy not to turn my life upside down and marry her.

question: She could be a real dog.
answer: You go look.

question: Me?
answer: Just go to the window and check her out.

question: You're pathetic.
answer: See her?

question: There's a beautiful, whoa, a very beautiful girl.
answer: Yes.

question: But no book. Let me see, let me see... Wait a minute. There's a book with a flower, so it must be her.
answer: What does he look like?

question: There's a waiter blocking, I can't see her face. He's serving her a cup of tea and she's putting in three spoonfuls of sugar --
answer: Well, why shouldn't she?

question: No reason. Unless she has hypoglycemia. Oh, he's moving.
answer: Can you see her?

question: Yes.
answer: And? --

question: She's very pretty.
answer: She is. I knew she would be. She had to be.

question: She looks... I would say she has a little of the coloring of that Kathleen Kelly person.
answer: Kathleen Kelly of the bookstore.

question: Why not? You said you thought she was attractive.
answer: So what? Who cares about Kathleen Kelly?

question: Well, if you don't like Kathleen Kelly, I can tell you right now you ain't gonna like this girl.
answer: Why not?

question: Because it is Kathleen Kelly.
answer: Oh, God.

question: What are you going to do?
answer: Nothing.

question: You're going to let her just wait there?
answer: Yes. Yes I am. That's exactly what I'm going to do. Why not?

question: But she wrote the letters.
answer: Good night, Kevin. I'll see you tomorrow.

question: Good night, Kevin. I'll see you tomorrow.
answer: Oh, yes. I'm expecting someone. Please. Oh!

question: Kathleen Kelly. Hello. What a coincidence. Mind if I sit down?
answer: Yes I do. I'm expecting someone.

question: Pride and Prejudice.
answer: Do you mind?

question: I didn't know you were a Jane Austen fan. Not that it's a surprise. I bet you read it every year. I bet you just love Mr. Darcy, and that your sentimental heart beats wildly at the thought that he and whatever her name is are really, honestly and truly going to end up together.
answer: Would you please leave? Please?

question: I'll get up as soon as your friend comes. Is he late?
answer: The heroine of Pride and Prejudice is Elizabeth Bennet and she's one of the greatest, most complex characters ever written, not that you would know.

question: As a matter of fact I've read it.
answer: Well, good for you.

question: I think you'd discover a lot of things if you really knew me.
answer: If I really knew you, I know what I would find -- instead of a brain, a cash register, instead of a heart, a bottom line.

question: What is it?
answer: I just had a breakthrough, and I have to thank you for it. For the first time in my life, when confronted with a horrible, insensitive person I actually knew what I wanted to say and I said it.

question: I think you have a gift for it. It was a splendid mixture of poetry and meanness.
answer: Meanness? Let me tell you --

question: Don't misunderstand me, I'm just paying you a compliment.
answer: Why are you doing this?

question: What have we have? A red, no, crimson rose, tucked into the pages. Something you read about in a book, no doubt. One of those books with a lady in a nightgown on the cover about to throw herself off a cliff. It's a joke to you, isn't it? Everything's a joke to you. You know what the handkerchief reminds me of? The first day I met you --
answer: The first day you lied to me --

question: I didn't lie to you --
answer: You did too --

question: I did not --
answer: I thought all that Fox stuff was so charming. F-O-X.

question: I never lied about it --
answer: "Joe. Just call me Joe." As if you were one of those stupid 22-year-old girls with no last name. "Hi, I'm Kimberley." "Hi, I'm Janice." What's wrong with them? Don't they know you're supposed to have last names? It's like they're a whole generation of cocktail waitresses.

question: I am not a stupid 22-year-old girl --
answer: That's not what I meant --

question: And when I said the thing about the Price Club and cans of olive oil, that wasn't what I meant either --
answer: Oh, you poor sad multimillionaire. I feel so sorry for you.

question: I am going to take a wild guess that this isn't him, either. Who is he, I wonder. Not, I gather, the world's greatest living expert on Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, but someone else entirely. Will you be you be mean to him too? Will you start out sweet as sugar candy and then suddenly, miraculously, like a bolt from the blue, find that sharp little tongue of yours?
answer: No, I won't. Because the man who's coming here tonight is completely unlike you. The man who is coming here is kind and funny -- he has the most wonderful sense of humor --

question: But he's not here.
answer: If he's not here, he has a reason, because there is not a cruel or careless bone in his body. I can't expect you to know anything about a person like that. You've nothing but a suit.

question: I think something happened, something terrible and unexpected that made it impossible for him --
answer: What happened?

question: He wasn't able to make it.
answer: He stood you up.

question: What could have happened?
answer: Not possible.

question: Maybe there was a subway accident.
answer: Absolutely.

question: A train was trapped underground with him inside.
answer: And no phone.

question: Or an automobile accident. Those cab drivers are maniacs.
answer: They hit something and you slam right into that plastic partition.

question: His elbows could be in splints -- so he can't really dial --
answer: Or he could be in the hospital in one of those semi-private room with like --

question: It could be.
answer: Is there a picture? So that explains it.

question: He was in jail.
answer: And there was a phone --

question: -- but he got only one call and he had to use it to call his lawyer.
answer: You are so lucky.

question: Are you crazy? This man couldn't possibly be the rooftop killer.
answer: Remember when you thought Frank might be the Unabomber?

question: That was different.
answer: How long did you sit there all alone?

question: Not that long. Joe Fox came in --
answer: Joe Fox!

question: I don't want to talk about it. Let's get to work. There must be something to do. There's always something to do.
answer: He stood her up.

question: Keeping the store open doesn't keep your mother alive, although sometimes I think we all think it does.
answer: Who was it, Birdie? That you had the thunderbolt over?

question: But it wasn't meant to be.
answer: Why not?

question: He ran Spain.
answer: Spain?

question: She fell in love with Generalissimo Franco?
answer: Don't say that. We don't know that for sure.

question: Who else could it have been? It was probably around 1960 --
answer: I mean, it's not like he was something normal, like a socialist or an anarchist or something --

question: It happened in Spain. People do really stupid things in foreign countries.
answer: Absolutely. They buy leather jackets, they go see Flamenco, they ride in gondolas, they eat in restaurants where guitarists sing Malaguena sola Rosa, but they don't fall in love with fascist dictators. Birdie is a very kind person, she's practically my surrogate mother.

question: Well she's out of her mind.
answer: She is not.

question: I could never ever be with anyone who doesn't take politics as seriously as I do. A hot dog is singing. You need quiet while a hot dog is singing?
answer: I have something to tell you. I didn't vote.

question: What?
answer: In the last mayoral election, when Rudy Giuliani was running against Ruth Messinger, I went to get a manicure and forgot to vote.

question: Since when do you get manicures?
answer: Oh, I suppose you could never be with a woman who gets manicures.

question: Forget it. It's okay. I forgive you.
answer: You forgive me.

question: What's going on? Look, this has been a big week, you're closing the store --
answer: It's not that, Frank, really it's not. It's just... Frank...

question: I know, that was terrible of me.
answer: What was?

question: To jump all over you when I'm the one who's really... Oh, God, I don't know how to say this --
answer: What is it?

question: You're a wonderful person, Kathleen.
answer: So are you.

question: And I'm honored that you want to be with me because you would never be with anyone who wasn't truly worthy --
answer: I feel exactly the same way about you.

question: Oh, God, don't say that, please, that just makes it worse.
answer: What? You don't love me? Me either.

question: You don't love me? But we're so right for each other.
answer: I know. That woman on television, right? Sidney-Ann.

question: I mean, nothing's happened or anything.
answer: I think she's a Republican.

question: I can't help myself.
answer: Oh, somewhere out there, I'm sure. Somewhere -- In cyberspace. My store is closing this week. I own a store. Did I ever tell you that? Probably not. It's a lovely store --

question: Oh, somewhere out there, I'm sure. Somewhere -- In cyberspace. My store is closing this week. I own a store. Did I ever tell you that? Probably not. It's a lovely store --
answer: This is a tragedy. Honey, grab a copy of The Trumpet of the Swan. What are you going to do with yourself?

question: I don't know. I'm going to take some time. I have a little money saved. I'm almost looking forward to it -- I'm sure she is. It's not their fault. The truth is, the world is just... different.
answer: Do you have the "Shoe" books? I don't know. My friend told me my daughter has to read the "Shoe" books, so here I am.

question: Noel Streatfeild. Noel Streatfeild wrote Ballet Shoes and Skating Shoes and Theater Shoes and Movie Shoes... I'd start with Skating Shoes, it's my favorite, although Ballet Shoes is completely wonderful.
answer: Thank you.

question: I'm sorry. Asshole. I'm sorry. I don't know what to say. Truly I don't. And anything I do say will sound trite. I hope you feel better.
answer: What I was thinking was she'd probably make a great children's book either.

question: Why would you think that?
answer: She knows everything. She has flawless taste. She's famous for it. The salesmen swear by her. If she likes it, it sells. Period.

question: So you're going to offer her a job?
answer: Why not? What else has she got to do?

question: Now that she's destitute --
answer: Thanks to you.

question: Well, I can't imagine her working for you.
answer: Why not?

question: She has a horrible personality, she's... nice to everyone all the time. It's exhausting. And her staff turnover is ... non-existent. They've been there forever. Until... recently, when they all found out they were going to lose their jobs.
answer: Thanks to you.

question: Hello, Charlie, Veronica.
answer: Last time, we rode in an elevator, we made the deal of the century. What is going to happen this time?

question: Well we can't go to the Storybook Lady. I'll read you a story.
answer: Where did she go?

question: She had to close her store.
answer: Why?

question: She didn't have enough business.
answer: Why?

question: Well. Her store was very close to our store, and you know our store sells books at a slightly lower cost --
answer: Why?

question: Why do we sell at a lower cost? So more people can buy books.
answer: Why couldn't she sell that way too?

question: Because she's small and we're big. How about we go get some candy?
answer: So now she's gone and it's all your fault.

question: Personal means that she's gone forever, and now we'll never get another book from her as long as we ever live.
answer: Remember the man who worked with her?

question: No.
answer: Well I hired him.

question: What are you doing here?
answer: To us.

question: Father and son, together at last. That happened with Gillian?
answer: I've stayed here after, let's see, your mother, Laurette that ballet dancer --

question: -- the nanny --
answer: Was she the nanny? I forgot that. How ironic. Then there was the ice skater --

question: -- also the nanny --
answer: Really. How amazingly ironic. Sybil the astrologer.

question: Whose moon turned out to be in somebody else's house, as I recall.
answer: Just like Gillian.

question: Gillian ran off with someone?
answer: The nanny.

question: Nanny Maureen? Gillian ran off with Nanny Maureen? That's incredibly ironic.
answer: True true.

question: There's no other word for it.
answer: Who did you break up with?

question: Patricia. You met her.
answer: Would I like her? Just kidding. Isn't this great? Have some peanuts. Of course I have to live out of a suitcase for a least three weeks, and then there's the inevitable legal hassle, more of your inheritance down the drain.

question: Don't worry about it.
answer: I won't. But then I get to meet someone new. That's the easy part.

question: Oh, right, a snap to find the one single person in the world who fills your heart with joy.
answer: Don't be ridiculous. Have I ever been with anyone who fits that description? Have you?

question: On to the next.
answer: Isn't it a beautiful night?

question: Who is it?
answer: Joe Fox.

question: What are you doing here?
answer: May I please come up?

question: It's really not a good idea. I have a terrible cold, can you hear it? I'm sniffling and not really awake -- -- and vitamin C, so I would really appreciate it if you would come some other time --
answer: Kathleen?

question: Just a second.
answer: Hello.

question: What are you doing here?
answer: I heard you were sick and I was worried and I wanted to -- Is someone here?

question: Just the Home Shopping Network.
answer: Bought any porcelain dolls?

question: I was thinking about it. You put me out of business --
answer: I know that --

question: And now you turn up with flowers? Did you come to gloat?
answer: No.

question: To offer me a job --
answer: No, I wouldn't think of --

question: Because I have plans, I have lots of offers. I've been offered a job by -- well, actually by --
answer: My former?

question: Former?
answer: We broke up.

question: That's too bad. You seemed so perfect for each other. I don't mean to say things like that. No matter what you have done to me, there is no excuse for my saying anything like that. But every time I see you --
answer: Things like that just seem to fly out of your mouth.

question: Yes. I'm sorry. I'm starting over. Thank you for coming. Goodbye. Thank you for coming. Goodbye.
answer: I bought you flowers.

question: Oh. Thank you.
answer: Why don't I put them in water? You're sick. Sit down, please. Vase?

question: Upper left.
answer: George says hello. He told me you weren't feeling well.

question: How is George?
answer: Great. He's revolutionizing the place. No one is allowed to work in his department who doesn't have a Ph.D. in children's literature.

question: I love daisies.
answer: You told me.

question: They're so friendly. Don't you think they are the friendliest flower?
answer: I do.

question: When did you break up?
answer: Oh, a couple of weeks ago.

question: Everyone is breaking up. You. Me. This other person I know broke up with someone in an elevator. I think it was in an elevator. Or just outside it. Or after it. It got stuck. I think. And suddenly everything became clear. When I saw you, at the coffee place, I was waiting for him and I was --
answer: -- charming.

question: I was not charming.
answer: Well, you looked charming. Tea?

question: Upper right. I was upset. And I was horrible.
answer: Honey? I was horrible.

question: True. But I have no excuse.
answer: Whereas I am a horrible person and have no choice but to be horrible, is that what you're saying?

question: No I am not saying that because I am done saying horrible things, even to you.
answer: You did it again. I put you out of business. You're entitled to hate me.

question: I don't hate you --
answer: But you'll never forgive me. Like Elizabeth.

question: Who?
answer: Elizabeth Bennet in Pride and Prejudice. She was too proud --

question: I thought you hated Pride and Prejudice.
answer: -- or was she too prejudiced and Mr. Darcy too proud? I can never remember. It wasn't personal --

question: -- It was business. What is that supposed to mean? I am so sick of that. All it means is it's not personal to you, but it's personal to me, it's personal to a lot of people. What's wrong with personal anyway?
answer: Nothing.

question: I mean, whatever else anything is, it ought to begin by being personal. My head's starting to get funny. I have to go back to bed. Why did you stop by? I forget.
answer: I wanted to be your friend.

question: Oh.
answer: I knew it wasn't possible. What can I say? Sometimes a person just wants the impossible. Could I ask you something?

question: What?
answer: What happened with that guy at the cafe?

question: Nothing.
answer: But you're crazy about him --

question: Yes. I am.
answer: Then why don't you run off with him? What are you waiting for?

question: I don't actually know him.
answer: Really.

question: We only know each other -- oh God, you're not going to believe this --
answer: Let me guess. From the Internet.

question: Yes.
answer: You've Got Mail.

question: Yes.
answer: Very powerful words.

question: Yes.
answer: I'm happy for him. Although -- could I make a little suggestion? I think you should meet him. No. I take it back. Why meet him?

question: I hardly think I need advice from someone who --
answer: I concede I bring out the worst in you, but let me help you not to say something you'll just torture yourself about for years to come. I hope you're better soon. It would be a shame to miss New York in the spring.

question: Thank you for the daisies.
answer: Take care.

question: I will.
answer: Goodbye.

question: I have been thinking about this and I think we should meet.
answer: We should meet. And we will meet. But I'm in the middle of a project that needs... ... tweaking. Tweaking?

question: That's what he said.
answer: He's probably married.

question: That's a terrible thing to say. It's not possible.
answer: Have you asked him if he's married? Have you said, "Are you married?"
